context: In psychology, memory is the <a0_0><b5_0>process in which information is encoded, stored, and retrieved.<b5_0/><a0_0/> <b6_0>Encodin<a1_0>g allows information from the outside world to be sensed in the form of chemical and physical stimuli<b6_0/>.<a1_0/> In the first stage the information must be changed so that it may be put into the encoding process. <a2_0>Storage<a2_0/> is the second memory stage or process. This entails that information is maintained over short periods of time. Finally the third process is the <a3_0><b7_0><b8_0>retrieval of information that has been stored<b7_0/><a3_0/>.<b8_0/> Such information must be located and returned to the consciousness. Some retrieval attempts may be effortless due to <a4_0><b9_0>the type of information, and other attempts to remember stored information may be more demanding for various reasons<b9_0/>.
